misconceptions.name: Implementing a completely different problem than the specification
misconceptions.description: The student implemented an average acceleration calculator (reading v0, v1, and t as doubles) instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding of or inattention to the given problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit a solution that computes average acceleration using v0, v1, and t for this question, even though the prompt mentions reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each question, the program must directly address the given problem statement. In this case, the code must read exactly 5 integers, use a loop and an even-number check (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only those even numbers, and print that sum in the required format. Writing code for a different textbook problem (average acceleration) does not satisfy this question.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of "Enter 5 integers".
Program reads three double values with nextDouble() instead of five integers.
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints "The average acceleration is ...".
No loop, no modulus operator %, and no accumulation of a sum of even numbers are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook or assignment questions (e.g., reusing an average acceleration example) or not carefully re-reading the problem statement before coding and submitting.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or set aside the average-acceleration code and re-design the solution starting from the actual requirements: (1) declare an int sum initialized to 0; (2) use a loop that runs 5 times, reading an int each time; (3) inside the loop, use if (n % 2 == 0) to check if the number is even and, if so, add it to sum; (4) after the loop, print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by sum. Finally, run your program with the sample input (3 8 2 7 4) and verify that it prints 14.
related_concepts: Testing against sample input and output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, arithmetic formula, output string) matches an average acceleration exercise and conflicts with the stated task of summing even numbers, indicating a systematic mismatch rather than a minor oversight.

evidence.note: The entire program is structured around computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t, with no reading of 5 integers, no loop, no even-number test, and no sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.task: Reading 5 integers from input, Loop structure to process inputs, Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0), Accumulating sum and printing result
misconceptions.name: Solved Incorrect Problem/Submitted Wrong File
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating average acceleration (using v0, v1, and t) instead of the assigned task of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program is correctly addressing the prompt's requirements, or they have accidentally submitted code intended for a different, unrelated assignment (e.g., a physics problem calculating acceleration).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assigned task (Q1: Sum of Even Numbers) requires reading five integer inputs, using a loop structure, and conditional logic (`% 2 == 0`) to find and sum the even numbers.
symptoms: Code structure calculates acceleration.
Variables v0, v1, and t are used.
Input types are doubles instead of integers.
Reads only 3 inputs instead of 5.
Missing loop and conditional logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the problem prompt, submitting the wrong file for Q1, or confusing the requirements with another assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully re-read the assignment prompt for 'Q1. Sum of Even Numbers' and implement the required logic: 1) Initialize a sum variable, 2) Use a loop to read 5 separate inputs, 3) Inside the loop, use an if statement and the modulo operator (%) to check if the current number is even, 4) If it is even, add it to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the code, including variable names (v0, v1, t) and the arithmetic operation (acceleration = (v1-v0)/t), confirms the student is solving an acceleration problem, not the required summation problem.

evidence.note: The class name, input prompt, variable names, and calculation all relate to acceleration, not summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Sequential Input Reading Instead of Loop
misconceptions.description: The student reads inputs sequentially line by line without using a loop structure, demonstrating a procedural flaw when handling multiple, repeated input operations (which the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem requires).
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to call the input function once for every item needed, regardless of how many items there are.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When repetitive operations are performed on a fixed number of inputs (like asking for 5 numbers), a loop structure (for/while) is the appropriate tool for elegant and scalable code.
symptoms: Multiple copies of 'input.nextDouble()' are used.
Input operations are not contained within any iterative structure.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding regarding the use case for iteration/loops when processing multiple data entries of the same type.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: To process multiple inputs (like the 5 required in the actual assignment), use a 'for' loop that runs N times (e.g., 5 times). Inside the loop, read the input and process it.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: While the student was solving the wrong problem, the structure they used for reading the 3 parameters (three separate reads) confirms they are not utilizing any iteration technique.

evidence.note: Three inputs are read sequentially without any loop structure, indicating a failure to use iteration, which is required for the actual assignment's 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has written code to calculate acceleration from physics (reading v0, v1, and t) instead of solving the assigned problem which requires reading 5 integers and summing even numbers. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of what problem they were asked to solve.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving a physics acceleration problem rather than the sum-of-even-numbers problem specified in Q1.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 asks to read exactly 5 integers from the user and calculate/print the sum of only the even numbers among those 5 integers.
symptoms: Code reads only 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code performs acceleration calculation (v1-v0)/t instead of filtering and summing even numbers
Output message says 'The average acceleration is' instead of 'Sum of even numbers:'
No loop structure present to handle 5 inputs
No modulo operator or even/odd checking logic
No accumulator for summing even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have copied code from a different assignment or exercise (acceleration calculator) and submitted it for Q1 without reading the problem statement carefully. This suggests either inattention, confusion about which file to submit, or lack of understanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read Q1 requirements. Write a new program that: (1) reads exactly 5 integers using a loop, (2) checks each number with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it's even, (3) accumulates the sum of only even numbers, (4) prints the result in the specified format.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation from physics) that is unrelated to the sum-of-even-numbers requirement. The variable names (v0, v1, t), the mathematical formula, and the output message all confirm this is the wrong solution.

evidence.note: Code reads only 3 values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as required by Q1
Calculates acceleration using physics formula instead of summing even numbers
Class name 'AccelerationCalculatorQ1' indicates this is acceleration calculator code, not a sum-of-even-numbers solution

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (average acceleration) instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t, rather than reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process those inputs, check which of them are even using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Code reads three double values instead of five integers.
No loop is present to handle 5 separate inputs.
No conditional check using the modulus operator (n % 2 == 0).
Final output reports average acceleration rather than the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a different exercise about acceleration or misunderstood the problem statement, focusing on a physics formula instead of the specified sum-of-evens task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from scratch for this question. Use a loop that runs 5 times to read integers with nextInt(), check each value with n % 2 == 0, add even values to a running sum, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by the sum.
related_concepts: Using the modulus operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is dedicated to computing acceleration from v0, v1, and t; there is no trace of reading 5 integers, looping, or checking even numbers, indicating the student solved a different problem entirely.

evidence.note: The program reads three double values v0, v1, and t rather than five integers, which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers.
Computation and output are for average acceleration, with no logic for summing even numbers or using a loop/conditional as required by the task.

misconceptions.name: Non-responsiveness to Prompt Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different and irrelevant problem (Acceleration Calculator) instead of the requested task (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to write an acceleration calculator, or they submitted the wrong file for this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must follow the prompt requirements, which clearly ask for a program that reads 5 integers and calculates the sum of the even ones.
symptoms: Code implements calculations for v0, v1, and t, related to acceleration.
Input prompt requests 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
The overall structure and logic do not address even number summation.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, submitting an incorrect file, or severe confusion about which problem to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the assignment instructions for 'Q1. Sum of Even Numbers' and implement the required logic (reading 5 inputs, using a loop, checking for even numbers, and accumulating the sum).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, the student code is for an entirely different physics problem (acceleration calculation) and bears zero resemblance to the prompt requirements.

evidence.note: The class name and input prompts indicate a problem unrelated to finding the sum of even numbers.
The core logic calculates acceleration (v1-v0)/t, entirely sidestepping the required tasks of reading 5 numbers, checking parity, and accumulating a sum.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage for Problem
misconceptions.description: Although solving the wrong problem, the student used 'double' to read inputs v0, v1, and t, whereas the required problem explicitly asks for '5 integers', implying the use of 'int' or at least processing the inputs as whole numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that all numerical inputs should be read as 'double' data types, or that floating point numbers are acceptable when 'integers' are requested.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading and processing 'integers'. While using a 'double' is technically possible, doing so introduces potential precision issues unnecessarily and requires careful handling if modulo operations (n % 2) were to be applied, which are typically defined for integer types.
symptoms: Use of input.nextDouble() for reading inputs.
Variables v0, v1, t, temp1, and acceleration are all defined as double.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to the specification of integer input, or a habit of defaulting to doubles for numerical input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For problems requiring counting or parity checks, ensure variables are defined as 'int' and use 'input.nextInt()' for reading input specified as integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence that if the student were to attempt the actual problem, they would incorrectly use doubles based on this evidence.

evidence.note: All inputs are read as doubles using nextDouble(), conflicting with the problem requirement for 'integers'.

misconceptions.name: Solving Wrong Problem - Complete Task Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for an acceleration calculation problem instead of the sum-of-evens problem. This indicates either a serious misreading of requirements or copy-pasting from previous work without adaptation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the acceleration problem (calculating a = (v1 - v0) / t from three user inputs), not the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly requires reading exactly 5 integers, checking which are even (n % 2 == 0), and summing only those. No acceleration calculation is involved.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Calculates and outputs acceleration, not sum of even numbers
No loop structure for handling 5 inputs
No conditional logic for filtering even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Severe misreading of problem requirements or inadvertent submission of code from a different assignment without reviewing the actual Q1 requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the problem statement. Identify: (1) How many inputs? (2) What type? (3) What calculation? (4) What output? Then code matches the actual requirements, not a memorized pattern from another task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is explicitly from an acceleration calculation problem (variables named v0, v1, t, acceleration; formula a = (v1-v0)/t). This cannot be the correct solution for 'sum of even numbers' problem. Confidence is near certain.

evidence.note: This is the acceleration formula a = (v1 - v0) / t with prompt asking for 'v0, v1, and t'. This is a completely different problem than 'sum of even numbers from 5 integers'.
Output is acceleration, not sum of even numbers. This confirms the student is solving the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Selection - Double vs Integer
misconceptions.description: Student reads input as double when the problem explicitly requires integers. While double can represent integer values, the semantic mismatch suggests lack of attention to type specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using double is acceptable for storing integer inputs, or didn't notice/care about the type specification.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies 'integers', use the int data type for reading and storing them. While double can mathematically represent integers, using the correct type reflects proper problem comprehension and good practice.
symptoms: Lines 8, 11, 14 use input.nextDouble() instead of input.nextInt()
Variables v0, v1, t declared as double not int
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely copy-pasted code from acceleration problem (which naturally requires doubles) without adjusting to this problem's integer requirement. Or general inattention to type specifications in problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change nextDouble() to nextInt() and declare variables as int instead of double. Always match the data type to the problem specification.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses double throughout, which is wrong for an integer problem. However, this might be secondary to the main issue of solving the wrong problem entirely.

evidence.note: Problem specifies 'integers' but code reads and stores as double. Should be int and nextInt().

misconceptions.name: No Loop Used for Repeated Input Pattern
misconceptions.description: Student reads three individual values with separate statements instead of using a loop. This suggests either no understanding of how loops handle repeated operations, or failure to recognize this as a repeated input scenario.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that individual input statements are better/equivalent to a loop for reading multiple values, or didn't think to use a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When reading n values following a similar pattern, use a loop (for or while) to iterate n times. Loops avoid code duplication and scale better. The problem requires reading 5 integers, which demands a loop structure.
symptoms: Three separate input.nextDouble() calls instead of one loop
Three separate debug println statements
Cannot scale to reading 5 values without rewriting code
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either doesn't understand loop benefits, didn't recognize this as a 'repeated input' scenario, or just copied a sequential input pattern without adaptation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop: for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... } This makes the code concise and the intent clear.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads only 3 values sequentially, not 5 in a loop. However, this might be due to copying the wrong solution rather than a genuine conceptual gap.

evidence.note: Three separate input statements with individual debug output. No loop used to read 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Conditional Logic for Filtering Even Numbers
misconceptions.description: Student has no conditional statement to check if a number is even (n % 2 == 0). The code performs an arithmetic operation (acceleration) instead of a filter operation (checking evenness).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to not understand that filtering requires checking a condition for each value, and only processing (summing) those that pass the condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, check each input with if(num % 2 == 0) before adding to the sum. The modulo operator gives the remainder; if remainder is 0, the number is even.
symptoms: No if statement in the code
No use of modulo operator (%)
No conditional filtering of any kind
Calculates acceleration instead of filtering evens
misconceptions.root_cause: Student didn't implement the core algorithm requirement. Either didn't understand what 'sum only even numbers' means, or didn't attempt to code this problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a conditional inside the input loop: if(num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; } This checks each number and only adds it if even.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains zero conditional logic. Critical for this problem.

evidence.note: Code performs arithmetic calculation (v1 - v0) / t with no conditional logic for checking evenness. Missing if(num % 2 == 0) checks entirely.

misconceptions.name: Missing Accumulator Pattern for Sum
misconceptions.description: Student has no sum variable that accumulates even numbers. Instead, the code calculates a single arithmetic result (acceleration). The accumulator pattern is fundamental for this type of problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to not recognize that summing multiple values requires a running total variable that gets updated inside the loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Initialize int sum = 0; before the loop, then use sum += num; inside the loop (when the number is even) to accumulate. After the loop, print the sum.
symptoms: No sum variable initialization
No accumulation sum += ... statement
Single calculation instead of accumulation
Output is a calculated value (acceleration), not a sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Student didn't implement the required algorithm. The code is from a different problem type (calculate single result vs. accumulate multiple results).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Initialize int sum = 0; at the start. Then inside the loop, when you detect an even number with if(num % 2 == 0), add sum += num; After the loop, print sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code contains no sum variable or accumulation logic. This is a core requirement missing entirely.

evidence.note: Output is a single calculated value (acceleration), not a sum of accumulated even numbers. No sum variable or accumulation pattern present.
